Course Title: Down and Dirty: Science, The Psyche, and Philosophies of Abjection
This is an interdisciplinary course which brings together science and philosophy to confront not merely what is abject, but explore the questions of: What makes us respond with abjection? What makes us coil in horror and disgust? What kind of limitations do we establish when we turn away from that which disturbs us? These are some guiding questions as we turn to philosophical topics of `filth' in terms of the psyche, sex, race, conspiracies, etc. while extending these theoretical explorations into the realm of science and our relationships to it. This course will further cover the basics of how to conduct research in biological sciences in order to expose students to the mechanisms of scientific development and how to approach and draw conclusions from scientific literature. The philosophical and the scientific will come together in applying the theoretical explorations of the abject in analyses of the science to which our immediate reaction is - GROSS!
course_description: A side-car course brings together a subset of students from two courses that overlap in methodologies, topics, etc., to create a short interdisciplinary course that runs simultaneously with its two sponsoring courses. One credit, S/U only. Schedule and format arranged by sponsoring professors.
